search.slidetext: developing a monitoringand evaluation plan for food security andagriculture programmes i accept terms and conditions of use please, accept our terms and conditions, then click on start course to begin

course overview this e-learning course on developing a monitoring and evaluation (m&e) plan for food security and agriculture programmes has been designed to support countries and regions in planning all the information needs for monitoring, pilotage and evaluation during the life of their food and nutrition security and agriculture programmes. the course offers practical guidance on building an m&e system which is feasible, practical and relevant to the programme’s needs. although the course focuses on large-scale development programmes that address food insecurity, the approaches and methods presented are equally applicable to smaller projects. the target audience for this course includes professionals involved in managing a programme, designing an m&e system, leading research or implementing m&e activities, and all those who wish to have concrete guidance on how to apply m&e methods to their programmes.

before you start learning, take a look at some navigation and course features by clicking on the markers. 4 1 3 2 do you need support? for technical support:elearning-support@fao.org before contacting us, please consult the faq section on our website. click on the numbers to read more quick tutorial
lesson 2 lesson 3 lesson 4 lesson 5 lesson 6 lesson 1 below you can read the description of each lesson. click on each tab to read more lessons description

lesson 1: introduction 20 minutes this lesson reviews the importance of monitoring and evaluation for the effective management of a programme. it also gives you an overview of what this course offers and how it is organized.

%currentslide%/%totalslides1% learning objectives this lesson will introduce you to the purpose and structure of this course. at the end of this lesson, you will be aware of the importance of planning for monitoring and evaluation (m&e) so that you will deliver accurate and useful information about your programme's achievements. you will also find out what this course offers and how it is organized.

%currentslide%/%totalslides1% introduction if you do not measure results, you can not tell success from failure. if you can not see success, you can not reward it. if you can not reward success, you are probably rewarding failure. if you can not see success, you can not learn from it. if you can not recognize failure, you can not correct it. if you can demonstrate results, you can win public support. adapted from osborne & gaebler, 1992.

monitoring and evaluation (m&e) is understood to be a necessary and efficient process to deliver development results. but, too often, officers in the field are too busy with implementation issues to concentrate on m&e. however, m&e is not something you can add to your programme as an afterthought. it is actually a part of your programme, and is as crucial to its success as the activities you plan to roll out. this course will guide you step-by-step in the development of a sound m&e system. %currentslide%/%totalslides1% a m&e system is a system for planning for all the information needs for monitoring and evaluation during the life of a programme. introduction

let's meet sharifa, a newly appointed programme manager in a development organization. why planning for m&e? %currentslide%/%totalslides1% hello. my name is sharifa. i have been appointed programme manager of a country programme aimed at improving the food security of small farmers. i have already done some monitoring and evaluation of a project, but it is my first experience at programme level. sharifa's programme includes training to help farmers increase their productivity as well as several activities aimed at improving the country’s legislation framework.

why does sharifa need an m&e system? why planning for m&e? %currentslide%/%totalslides1% planning for m&e is always good practice, even at project level. but at programme level, it is a necessity. programmes usually aim at many target groups, at many levels and in many places. you may know only a few of the beneficiaries, but not the majority. you need a well-planned m&e system so that you know what is actually going on with the programme and can make decisions accordingly. programmes also usually comprise many activities, all of which are monitored and are delivering data and information. you need an m&e system in order to avoid being overwhelmed with information and so that the decisions you make are accurate. difference between projects and programmes

let's have a look at the m&e experience of three colleagues working in the food and nutrition security field. why planning for m&e? %currentslide%/%totalslides1% mulat leila clara click on the picture to learn about their experience with m&e

plan for data collection an m&e system provides most of the data that you will use, and, even more importantly, gives you the plan for data collection. learn to improve your programme it is also the m&e system that provides the necessary information to improve the programme, year after year, but also to better design and implement the next programme. make sure your work will be used an m&e system includes all the procedures and arrangements to make sure that the data collected is used for decision-making. as previous testimonials show, the m&e system will help you to... benefits of a results-based m&e system %currentslide%/%totalslides1% define your objectives an m&e system helps you make sure that your objectives are well understood and achievable.

the m&e system is a necessary condition to achieving result-based management in your programme. what is result-based management (rbm)? benefits of a results-based m&e system %currentslide%/%totalslides1% rbm is a management strategy by which all actors, contributing directly or indirectly to achieving a set of results, ensure that their processes, products and services contribute to the achievement of desired results (that is, outputs, outcomes and higher-level goals or impact). the actors, in turn, use information and evidence on actual results to inform decision-making on the design, resourcing and delivery of programmes and activities for accountability and reporting.

results-based management (rbm) is a life-cycle approach to m&e. each step must be done correctly to allow for the next step to proceed efficiently. for example, if you do not set your objectives well, it will be difficult to collect the right data for monitoring. similarly, it will be unlikely that you will collect data in a timely way and launch evaluations when needed if you do not plan ahead. rbm also helps you draw lessons from experience and is, therefore, beneficial for the next programme you will design and implement. benefits of a results-based m&e system %currentslide%/%totalslides1% as you can see, monitoring and evaluation is actually a part of any project, and is as crucial to the programme's success as the activities you plan to roll out. the rbm life-cycle approach source: undg rbm handbook.

in the framework of a project or a programme, engaging in rbm means that: benefits of a results-based m&e system %currentslide%/%totalslides1% are you willing to engage in rbm? you will explicitly define the goal of the programme (what it is for?) and the objectives that you want to pursue. you will make sure to collect data on the implementation and achievements of the programme, from year one and until the end. you will make decisions based on the information collected and what it tells you about the results obtained.

designing the m&e system is also a good opportunity to involve stakeholders in the implementation of the programme, and to make them commit to its success. benefits of a results-based m&e system %currentslide%/%totalslides1% when the results live up to expectations, it is also a good opportunity for you and your coworkers to promote and celebrate your work, which will enhance team spirit. and if you don't achieve your results, you will be able to explore the reasons why with accurate and useful information from m&e. involve stakeholders

the information provided by the monitoring and evaluation system will help your institution and your partners better understand the programme and the way it works, and you will be able to share this knowledge with other stakeholders. your institution will be accountable for the outcomes and impacts it said it would achieve, and will be able to demonstrate to the other stakeholders that it can do what it promised. this may also help when considering further programme development at country level. benefits of a results-based m&e system %currentslide%/%totalslides1%

what does the course offer? %currentslide%/%totalslides1% so, why should you take this course? if you are involved in managing a programme, designing an m&e system, leading research or implementing m&e activities, and you wish to have concrete guidance on how to apply m&e methods to your programme, this course offers practical guidance on building an m&e system which is feasible, practical and relevant to your needs. what is not covered in this course? the course focuses on how to apply m&e methods to your programme, rather than describing m&e theories in detail. however, to learn more about specific topics related to m&e, you can refer to the resources listed in the course.

defining your indicators what does the course offer? %currentslide%/%totalslides1% choosing what to monitor planning for m&e activities basic m&e concepts m&e indicators: basic concepts the resources provided with this course will help you to complete this task. through sharifa's example, you will look at several components of an m&e plan that you can build lesson by lesson for your particular project or programme.

summary a monitoring and evaluation (m&e) system is a system for planning all the information needs for monitoring, pilotage and evaluation during the life of a programme. in programmes, where you can not directly observe changes, an m&e system is needed to know what is actually going on, so that you can make decisions accordingly. this course will offer you step-by-step guidance to prepare an m&e plan for your project or programme. the course also provides a series of job aids and references for additional resources where you can find more in-depth information on various aspects of m&e. %currentslide%/%totalslides1%

lesson 2: basic m&e concepts 30 minutes this lesson explains a few basic concepts about monitoring and evaluation (m&e). it answers questions like: what is m&e? what is it for? what are the differences between monitoring and evaluation?
%currentslide%/%totalslides2% learning objectives at the end of this lesson, you will be able to: define monitoring and evaluation (m&e); identify differences between monitoring and evaluation.

basic m&e concepts defining your indicators choosing what to monitor planning for m&e activities m&e indicators: basic concepts introduction %currentslide%/%totalslides2% basic m&e concepts before starting your m&e plan, you need to know a few basic concepts about programme monitoring and evaluation. would you be able to answer the questions below? if you want to refresh your memory on those concepts, you can look at the next screens of this lesson. otherwise, you can skip it and go directly to lesson 3: choosing what to monitor. what is monitoring and evaluation? what is it for? what are the differences between monitoring and evaluation?

let's learn more about monitoring and evaluation through sharifa's experience. though you need to plan for both of them, monitoring and evaluation are two distinct activities. %currentslide%/%totalslides2% a component of sharifa's programme aims to improve food security at country level by helping small farmers increase their productivity, and it does so via training activities. monitoring and evaluation

monitoring is a continuous process of collecting data to verify whether the objectives of your programme are likely to be attained, and taking corrective actions when needed. monitoring is usually done by identifying expected results at each step of the programme and the indicators to assess these results. monitoring %currentslide%/%totalslides2% continuous process let's consider, for example, sharifa's programme steps: impact level example of monitoring indicator interpretation outcome level output level activity level input level programme step click on each tab to read more

%currentslide%/%totalslides2% by definition, monitoring activities only rely on data that you can easily and regularly retrieve from activity reports, field visits of community workers, aggregation of external data, or, sometimes, via surveys. a monitoring system is an effective way to know if the programme is running smoothly and if it is likely to be successful. it is also the best way to make an early identification of any issue that may arise. it allows you to investigate challenges with additional data collection, and sometimes with an evaluation, to understand what is happening so that you can take corrective measures. goals monitoring

%currentslide%/%totalslides2% please select the answer of your choice programme designers and programme staff. a wider audience, including donors and programme beneficiaries. monitoring in your opinion, what is the main audience for monitoring?

evaluation is the systematic assessment of a project, programme or policy, its design, implementation and results. it is usually done once or twice in the lifetime of a programme: first, to be sure that the programme is going in the right direction and to tweak activities if needed, and then, at the very end of the programme, to assess its impacts. source: oecd dac glossary. evaluation %currentslide%/%totalslides2%

in an evaluation, you would usually ask questions in order to assess the results of the programme. evaluation questions help set the direction of the work and ensure that the answers will be useful to you and your team. evaluation %currentslide%/%totalslides2% let's look at some examples of questions that sharifa could develop for her programme: effectiveness definition example question relevance internal coherence(consistency) external coherence efficiency(i.e. cost-effectiveness) evaluation theme click on each tab to read more

large audience especially for accountability purposes large audience especially for accountability purposes %drag01% %currentslide%/%totalslides2% %drag02% %drag03% check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer sporadic; once or twice in the lifetime sporadic; once or twice in the lifetime %drag04% monitoring and evaluation differ significantly. try to associate the right features to each. comparing monitoring and evaluation please drag and drop the items in the corresponding box and click on check answer programme management and staff programme management and staff continuous continuous monitoring audience timing evaluation audience timing audience timing

%drag01% %currentslide%/%totalslides2% %drag02% %drag03% check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer %drag04% monitoring and evaluation answer different questions, especially at impact level: comparing monitoring and evaluation please drag and drop the items in the corresponding box and click on check answer what happened? do the observed changes go in the right direction? what happened? do the observed changes go in the right direction? did we contribute to what happened? how and why did we achieveour objectives? did we contribute to what happened? how and why did we achieveour objectives? monitoring evaluation

%drag01% %currentslide%/%totalslides2% %drag02% %drag03% check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer %drag04% monitoring and evaluation rely on a different set of tools: comparing monitoring and evaluation please drag and drop the items in the corresponding box and click on check answer project-level activity reports, field visits, aggregation of external data,small-scale surveys. project-level activity reports, field visits, aggregation of external data,small-scale surveys. advanced statistical analyses, large-scale surveys, series of interviews with stakeholders, focus groups, case studies. advanced statistical analyses, large-scale surveys, series of interviews with stakeholders, focus groups, case studies. monitoring evaluation

%drag01% %currentslide%/%totalslides2% %drag02% %drag03% check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer %drag04% monitoring and evaluation are also conducted by different actors. comparing monitoring and evaluation please drag and drop the items in the corresponding box and click on check answer it is usually done internally. it is usually done internally. it is usually done by someoneexternal to the team. it is usually done by someoneexternal to the team. monitoring evaluation

in short, we can summarize the difference between monitoring and evaluation by saying that... comparing monitoring and evaluation %currentslide%/%totalslides2% monitoring tracks your progress towards achieving your objectives... ...tells you if the situation changes as expected. evaluation tells you if your programme made the difference, and how. evaluation aims at assessing the impact of your programme. monitoring is a programme management tool. we can also say that... outputs outcomes impacts activities

and, finally, let's note that evaluation strongly benefits from a good monitoring system, in a variety of ways: comparing monitoring and evaluation %currentslide%/%totalslides2% good monitoring makes the evaluation more focused: when data about activities, outputs and first outcomes are already collected and analysed, the evaluation can build upon these data and focus on more interesting questions such as the impacts of the programme. good monitoring makes the evaluation more relevant: if you already know about what has changed, the evaluation can focus on the how and why, and learning lessons from experience. good monitoring makes the evaluation more accurate: if an issue has been spotted thanks to monitoring, the evaluation can investigate it. designing and implementing an evaluation

summary monitoring is a continuous process of collecting data to verify whether the objectives of your programme are likely to be attained, and taking corrective actions when needed. it can be considered as a programme management tool. evaluation is a systematic and objective assessment of an ongoing or completed project, programme or policy, its design, implementation and results. monitoring and evaluation differ in terms of audience, timing, purposes and actors. good monitoring makes the evaluation more focused, relevant and accurate. %currentslide%/%totalslides2%

lesson 3: choosing what to monitor 40 minutes this lesson will help you define the expected outcomes of your programme in collaboration with your stakeholders, and formulate relevant m&e questions to help you identify the information you will need.

%currentslide%/%totalslides3% learning objectives at the end of this lesson, you will be able to: identify the components of a results matrix, including assumptions and risks; apply a series of criteria to choose what to monitor; describe a possible process for involving stakeholders in the monitoring and evaluation (m&e) system.

basic m&e concepts defining your indicators choosing what to monitor planning for m&e activities m&e indicators: basic concepts introduction %currentslide%/%totalslides3% setting up a monitoring and evaluation (m&e) system is all about providing yourself with the means to measure your results. but you need to know what is important to know and why both for you and your stakeholders. choosing what to monitor will be the main topic of this lesson. choosing what to monitor

to identify your information needs, you can rely on the results matrix of your programme. reviewing the results matrix, defining your m&e questions and involving stakeholders in the m&e system will be the main topics of this lesson. %currentslide%/%totalslides3% introduction what does the results matrix say? what are the right m&e questions? 2 how do we involve the stakeholders? 3 1

once the programme has been approved and within the first months of its implementation, you will need to design and build the m&e system.the first step will be to review the results matrix of your programme and adapt it to your needs. review the results matrix %currentslide%/%totalslides3% what is a results matrix? the results matrix explains how results are to be achieved, including causal relationships and underlying assumptions and risks. the results framework reflects a more strategic level across an entire organization for a country programme, a programme component within a country programme, or even a project.source: undp rbm handbook. the results matrix is a variation of the logical framework (or logframe). today, most projects and programmes are designed using tools that make the intervention logic explicit, such as log frames and results matrix tools. what does the results matrix say? where are you in the results-based management programme process? click on the picture for more information 1

%currentslide%/%totalslides3% see what some colleagues say about results matrices. with which of them do you agree more? review the results matrix select an opinion to read more i’ve done tons of logframes in the past because donors ask for them. but when we needed to use them for evaluation, they were almost always obsolete and useless. the logframe has been our programme’s m&e roadmap: you need to update it at regular intervals, but then it really helps when rewiewing our progress towards our objectives.

below you will find the results matrix for sharifa's programme. the "indicator" column has been removed because, for now, it is important to focus on the intervention logic (or results chain) of the programme. %currentslide%/%totalslides3% do you remember sharifa's programme? the programme aims at improving food security at country level by helping small farmers increase their productivity with different activities. here, we focus on priority 3 of the programme, which aims at enhancing the legal framework for farmers. impact expected result outcome outputs activities inputs level of result click on each tab to read more review the results matrix see a diagram to better visualize the intervention logic tips for writing the results matrix

start by checking your programme. there is a good chance that it already contains an initial version of the results matrix which you can start with and improve. the results matrix is about helping you assess your progress towards your objectives. be sure to make the difference. %currentslide%/%totalslides3% review the results matrix the goal (or rationale) of sharifa's programme is to improve the livelihoods of rural people living on agriculture. the objective of the programme is to do so by supporting the development of a favourable policy environment. the goal is why you are doing it. the objective is how you expect to do it.

the operator (or implementing agency) of activities is sharifa's organization. government officers and agriculture stakeholders are the target groups, that is the people or organizations whose attitudes and practices need to change in order to solve the problem; (in this case, those who need to take into consideration the living conditions of rural people). the rural people are the beneficiaries, that is the people who will benefit from the programme if it is done well. %currentslide%/%totalslides3% identify the main stakeholders of your programme: review the results matrix your results chain will usually flow from activities performed by the operator to outputs/outcomes of target groups and outcomes/impacts of beneficiaries.

although the programme's objectives seem logical, we know that things are not that simple: the programme intervenes in a certain context that should also be taken into consideration. this is done by adding the assumptions and risks that apply to the intervention logic. what are assumption and risks?the undp results-based management handbook has a very clear definition of what assumptions and risks are: adding the assumptions and risks %currentslide%/%totalslides3% assumptions are the variables or factors that need to be in place for results to be achieved. they can be internal or external to the particular programme or organization. risk corresponds to a potential future event, fully or partially beyond one's control, that may (negatively) affect the achievement of results. assumptions risks programme context

%currentslide%/%totalslides3% do the sentences below refer to assumptions or risks? adding the assumptions and risks please drag and drop the sentences in the corresponding box and click on check answer assumptions risk %drag01% %drag02% %drag03% check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer %drag04% %drag05% %drag06% works budget and team are available. budget and team are available. international economic conditions could change. international economic conditions could change. the trainers are good enough to convey the key messages to participants. the trainers are good enough to convey the key messages to participants. possible situation of civil unrest. possible situation of civil unrest. agriculture stakeholders might not be involved in policy development processes. agriculture stakeholders might not be involved in policy development processes. government officers are present at the event and agree to discuss. government officers are present at the event and agree to discuss.

%currentslide%/%totalslides3% impact expected result assumptions and risks outcomes outputs activities inputs level of result click on each tab to read more it is easier to identify assumptions and risks after a few months of implementation, when you will better perceive the situation and will start facing difficulties. adding the assumptions and risks let's go back to our results matrix and add the assumptions and risks that apply to each step.

the more you progress in the implementation of the programme, the more you will be able to refine and improve your assumptions. it is, therefore, good practice to continuously improve your results matrix by updating the assumption column after the interim evaluation, and perhaps every year, by putting it on the agenda of m&e events. %currentslide%/%totalslides3% making the assumptions explicit is very important in a monitoring context, because you can except that if the outputs have been delivered and your assumptions have been verified, it is more likely that you will achieve the expected outcomes. of course, only evaluations will be able to tell you if you actually did so. you may also decide to monitor some of these assumptions, as explanatory variables of the intervention in your m&e system. adding the assumptions and risks risk and assumptions

%currentslide%/%totalslides3% to conclude, here are a few tips to quickly assess your results matrix, based on conell and kubisch (1998). your results matrix should be... assess the results matrix plausible agreed embedded testable does common sense or prior evidence suggest that the activities, if implemented, will lead to the desired results? is there reasonable agreement with the intervention logic as postulated? is the intervention logic embedded in a broader social and economic context, where assumptions and risks likely to influence the desired results are identified? is the intervention logic specific enough to measure its expected results in credible and useful ways? and we could add this one: is it clear and simple enough that you can explain it to a newly arrived coworker?

once you have revised your results matrix, it will be time to choose what to monitor. we will do this by asking questions that we will call m&e questions, but that are also sometimes called performance questions. to define your m&e questions, you can use the following key questions: define your m&e questions %currentslide%/%totalslides3% the matrix presented in the next screen can help you define your m&e questions. this can be done in a meeting, for instance. to whom? to do what? what information is the most likely to be useful? when? what are the right m&e questions? 2

programme manager think about your stakeholders when you define your m&e questions. they need information in order to... define your m&e questions %currentslide%/%totalslides3% project officer in charge of training agriculture stakeholders national government international donor …manage the programme, measure progress and take corrective action, if needed. …be accountable to donors and stakeholders. …gain new knowledge. click on each grey tab to read more

what are the most critical steps in the results chain to obtain the expected impacts? this is where we come back to the results chain itself. it is important to begin by asking: what is the most useful information? then, you need to go back to the results matrix to assess your needs systematically. %currentslide%/%totalslides3% impacts outcomes outputs activities of course, each audience has different needs... define your m&e questions

outcomes and impacts outcomes and impacts %drag01% %currentslide%/%totalslides3% %drag02% %drag03% check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer each audience will be interested in different steps of the results chain. can you identify the main focus for the following stakeholders? please drag and drop the each main focus in the corresponding box and click on check answer outputs and outcomes outputs and outcomes activities and outputs activities and outputs define your m&e questions outputs outcomes impacts activities have programme activities yielded the expected results? should we improve the programme? was the training workshop successful? did we make a difference? can we draw lessons from one country that would be useful in others? donor programme manager project officer

outputs outcomes impacts activities when monitoring at the programme level, you would typically concentrate on the output and outcome levels.you can simply synthesize information coming from the project(s) to know if everything is going as expected or not (i.e. assuming projects have an m&e system). %currentslide%/%totalslides3% define your m&e questions you will need more information only if the project does not have an m&e system. for instance... if a large proportion of the attendees of a training session later declare that they did not learn anything new, sharifa will launch further investigations to understand why: was the course content not relevant to the needs of the audience? was the teacher not good enough? then, she can work to improve the programme.

activities define your m&e questions %currentslide%/%totalslides3% also, take into consideration the time when the data will be needed. data related to inputs and activities can be crucial in the very first months of a programme, and will be needed less often later on. however, data related to the programme's outcomes will be important at its end. when? outcomes inputs

risk and assumptions is the political climate favourable to our programme? do governments follow our organization's strategic objectives with these new policies? %currentslide%/%totalslides3% what are the main risks or assumptions that may influence the achievements of the programme? which of them are already monitored? be careful when looking at the results matrix to also take into considerations assumptions and risks when asking your questions. for example... define your m&e questions it is likely that for many risks and assumptions, especially at the outcome and impact levels, the information will be available or already monitored by another organization. but for some of them, you may need to gather the data yourself.

%currentslide%/%totalslides3% in any case, the information that you need is: define your m&e questions is there any information that you will need to provide to an international organization? information that you do not already have by other means. information that may trigger a decision. information about events that could make your action irrelevant or inadequate. information that you can discuss with stakeholders and donors. click on each tab to read more

involvement is important not only for the sake of participation. experience has shown that a system is much more likely to function well when the suppliers and users of the information have been involved in its creation from the beginning. by contrast, a closed group of specialists will be tempted to construct an expensive, technically ideal system, which may never be operational. %currentslide%/%totalslides3% who are your stakeholders? it is good practice to involve the programme's stakeholders in the design and implementation of the m&e system, especially when revising the logframe and defining the right m&e questions. click on the picture for more information involve the stakeholders how do we involve the stakeholders? 3

involve the stakeholders %currentslide%/%totalslides3% how to involve stakeholders? you can follow the process below to define an m&e system by involving your stakeholders: click on the arrow to proceed first, someone should be nominated to be responsible for the m&e process. this person could be either the programme manager or another officer who will devote his/her time to this task.

job aids now it’s your turn! you can answer the questions in the template below to decide what to monitor: you can use the matrix below to define your m&e questions.this process can be done in a meeting, for instance. %currentslide%/%totalslides3% questions for choosing what to monitor matrix for defining your m&e questions

summary 1/2 the first step to design and build a monitoring and evaluation (m&e) system is to review the results matrix of your programme. the results matrix provides information about goals, objectives, stakeholders and expected results for each stage of the programme, including assumptions and risks. once you have reviewed and revised your results matrix, it is time to choose what to monitor, that is, to define your m&e questions (also called performance questions). m&e questions can be identified by answering the following questions: what information is the most likely to be useful? to whom? to do what? when? %currentslide%/%totalslides3%

summary 2/2 each audience will be interested in different steps of the results chain. monitoring at the programme level usually concentrates on the output and outcome levels. involving stakeholders in the process is crucial. this can be done by involving both users and suppliers of information when designing the m&e system. it is also advisable to involve an expert with recent and complete knowledge of exploitable statistical data. %currentslide%/%totalslides3%

lesson 4: m&e indicators: basic concepts 20 minutes this lesson answers a few basic questions about indicators, such as: what is an indicator? what are numerical indicators? what are the differences between: specific and generic indicators; elementary, derived and compound indicators; and programme and context indicators?

%currentslide%/%totalslides4% learning objectives at the end of this lesson, you will be able to: provide a definition of "indicator"; describe what indicators are particularly suited to m&e; explain the difference between specific and generic indicators; explain the difference between elementary, derived and compound indicators; explain the difference between programme and context indicators.

basic m&e concepts defining your indicators choosing what to monitor planning for m&e activities m&e indicators: basic concepts introduction %currentslide%/%totalslides4% m&e indicators: basic concepts selecting the right indicators is a crucial step in building your m&e plan. before making this selection, there are a few concepts that you should know in order to make the right choices. if you wish to review these concepts, please go through this lesson. otherwise, you can skip it and go directly to lesson 5: defining your indicators. what is an indicator? can numerical indicators provide information to answer both quantitative and qualitative questions? what are the differences between: specific and generic indicators; elementary, derived and compound indicators; and programme and context indicators?

an indicator can be defined as "the measurement of...". for example: %currentslide%/%totalslides4% what is an indicator? general level of awareness on the issue of rural livelihood in the government and the administration. a context variable share of the training sessions' budget used. a resource used share of trainees who would recommend this course to their colleagues. a gauge of quality share of trainees who used their new skills to improve the legislation on rural livelihood. an effect obtained share of targeted government officers who attended the training. an objective to be met

m&e indicators should help actors of public interventions to communicate, negotiate and/or make decisions. %currentslide%/%totalslides4% most of the time, indicators in an m&e system will focus on numerical (e.g. a share, a number) and categorical (e.g. "traffic lights" or scores) because they are better suited to decision-making. in an evaluation, where you want to understand why your programme works or does not, you may use a larger variety of indicators, including non-numerical ones. indicators in an evaluation what is an indicator?

%drag01% %currentslide%/%totalslides4% %drag02% %drag03% check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer %drag04% quantitative or numerical indicators can perfectly provide information to respond to quantitative and qualitative questions, as in the example below. can you put the elements below in the correct places? can indicators respond to both quantitative and qualitative questions? please drag and drop the elements in the corresponding box and click on check answer share of trainees who said they applied their new knowledge in a professional setting. share of trainees who said they applied their new knowledge in a professional setting. how many people have been trained? how many people have been trained? number of persons trained via training programme. number of persons trained via training programme. quantitative question quantitative output indicator qualitative question qualitative outcome indicator did the trainees use what they learned? did the trainees use what they learned?

%currentslide%/%totalslides4% a good indicator must provide simple information that both the supplier and the user can easily communicate and understand. to this end, you can use quantitative indicators, even for qualitative information. for example, surveying beneficiaries to find out about changes in knowledge, attitudes or practices (sometimes called "kap surveys") is quite straightforward and easy to do. can indicators respond to both quantitative and qualitative questions? using a scoring system makes qualitative and quantitative information easy to understand. using scoring for qualitative information

an indicator is said to be ad hoc or specific when it has been constructed specifically for the m&e of the programme. an indicator is generic when it is recognized as a standard way to measure a given phenomenon. for example, how would you classify the following indicators? specific and generic indicators %currentslide%/%totalslides4% check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer %set1% %set2% %set3% please select the answers of your choice (2 or more) and click on check answer share of targeted people who gained new skills following the training. share of ministry of agriculture (moa) officers who are now able to design and implement an m&e system following new regulations in the realm of rural livelihoods. generic specific output outcome output outcome share of trained moa officers who say that they were able to include more relevant m&e specifications in their legal production in the year following the course. share of trainees who used what they have learned.

in all cases, try to ensure that all projects within a programme use, as much as possible, the same set of indicators for similar activities, and that these indicators can feed your own programme indicators. this will help when comparing them and identifying problematic situations. generic indicators are typically a good choice to measure the outputs of most ‘classical activities’ such as training or investment programmes. but you may need to revert to ad hoc indicators when you are experimenting with a new set of activities. when building your m&e system, you will need to balance both types of indicators. specific and generic indicators specific indicators specific indicators, are usually better at measuring what you are trying to achieve, especially at the outcome level. actually, in an evaluation that deals with outcomes and impacts most, if not all indicators, are ad hoc. generic indicators generic indicators, on the other hand, are useful for comparison purposes. because they are often used in a large variety of contexts, they are also easier to deal with. %currentslide%/%totalslides4%

another important distinction is among elementary, derived and compound indicators. %currentslide%/%totalslides4% elementary, derived and compound indicators elementary indicators an elementary indicator provides basic information on which other indicators can be built. derived indicators a derived indicator is based on the calculation of the ratio between two elementary indicators. compound indicators a compound indicator is the weighted sum of several elementary or derived indicators.the indicators considered to be the most important are therefore given the most weight, while those considered to be least important are given the least weight. the value of the compound indicator is the sum of all the adjusted values of these indicators. example example example

how to use elementary, derived or compound indicators? %currentslide%/%totalslides4% elementary, derived and compound indicators elementary indicators are mostly the raw material that you will collect before analysis. in most cases, it is better to use ratios (i.e. derived indicators) which will be better at showing if you are about to reach the expected target (e.g. 70 percent of the target was trained). compound indicators can answer a complicated question with a single figure or a single score and are therefore useful for communication purposes, or to gain a broader view of a topic. however, the more complicated an indicator, the more difficult it is to decipher and, accordingly, to make the right decision.

%currentslide%/%totalslides4% finally, please consider that both programme and context indicators will probably be part of your m&e system. programme and context indicators a programme indicator aims at measuring the progress of your programme. it does so by monitoring the changes that are expected on targeted publics or territories. programmeindicators contextindicators in contrast, context indicators apply to an entire territory, population or category of population. context indicators are usually relevant to your programme, but their level is unlikely to change as a consequence of it. a context indicator always applies to the entire eligible territory or targeted public, without distinguishing between those who have been or will be reached by the programme and those who have not.

%drag01% %currentslide%/%totalslides4% %drag02% %drag03% check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer %drag04% what kind of indicator would answer the following questions? please drag and drop the questions in the corresponding box and click on check answer was rural livelihood a top priority in the country before the start of the programme? was rural livelihood a top priority in the country before the start of the programme? was the targeted population reached? was the targeted population reached? did the targeted population change their attitude towards the issue at stake? did the targeted population change their attitude towards the issue at stake? programme indicators what is the average education level of government officers in the country? what is the average education level of government officers in the country? programme and context indicators context indicators

summary an indicator can be defined as the measurement of: an objective to be met; an effect; quality; a resource used; a context variable. in an m&e system it is advisable to focus on numerical and categorical indicators, as they are best suited to the needs of accountability and decision-making. quantitative or numerical indicators can provide information to respond to both quantitative and qualitative questions. in defining your m&e system, you will need to balance: specific or "ad hoc" indicators and generic or "standard" indicators; elementary, derived and compound indicators; programme and context indicators. %currentslide%/%totalslides4%

lesson 5: defining your indicators 45 minutes this lesson provides step-by-step guidance on defining and building your indicators in a systematic and comprehensive way, starting with the m&e questions previously defined. you will also find criteria for assessing indicators' quality.

%currentslide%/%totalslides5% learning objectives at the end of this lesson, you will be able to: describe the steps for building an indicator table; apply criteria for selecting the right indicators; apply criteria for checking the quality of a given indicator.

basic m&e concepts defining your indicators choosing what to monitor planning for m&e activities m&e indicators: basic concepts introduction %currentslide%/%totalslides5% identifying indicators is a crucial part of an m&e plan. appropriate and well-defined indicators will help you to set realistic targets and monitor the progress of your programme efficiently, thus matching the information needs of different stakeholders. defining your indicators

%currentslide%/%totalslides5% this lesson will support you in the process of selecting indicators and defining them appropriately. introduction how can i construct my indicators? how can i select the most relevant ones? 2 how can i check their quality? 3 1

%currentslide%/%totalslides5% percentage of government officers trained. indicator defining your indicator an indicator is not just a ratio or a number. to make sure that its meaning, measurement and interpretation will be unequivocal in the next five years or so of the programme, you must define it in a more detailed way. did we manage to train all the government officers we had targeted? m&e question the definition should explain in detail how the indicator is measured. indicator = (a/b*100)%, where: a = number of government officers who completed the training sessions. b = estimated number of government officers who are likely to be involved in the design and implementation of policies impacting rural livelihoods (revised each year)... definition

%currentslide%/%totalslides5% percentage of government officers trained. indicator frequency most of the indicators of your m&e system will likely need to be calculated every year, to be included in the annual report. indicators relying on surveys (which is often the case for outcome indicators) may be calculated less frequently; for instance, at baseline, mid-term and in the final review. did we manage to train all the government officers we had targeted? m&e question every year. you also have to determine how frequently you will calculate your indicator. indicator = (a/b*100)%, where: a = number of government officers who completed the training sessions. b = estimated number of government officers who are likely to be involved in the design and implementation of policies impacting rural livelihoods (revised each year)... definition read more frequency

start with the data generated by your own programme such as project reports, activity reports, feedback questionnaires from your training sessions or your seminars, as well as observations in the field. at the activity and output levels, it is common to rely on these sources to define your indicators. then, think about the additional data you could retrieve from external sources, such as that for context indicators. %currentslide%/%totalslides5% to develop indicators, you need reliable information sources. as you know, by definition, the monitoring system only relies on data that you can easily and regularly collect. fortunately, there are many sources that you can turn to to feed your m&e system. you may, for example: information sources programme context finally, you can specifically collect data to address unanswered needs. this is usually done through surveys.

%currentslide%/%totalslides5% percentage of government officers trained. indicator in our indicator table, sharifa is adding a new section, "sources": did we manage to train all the government officers we had targeted? definition every year. frequency indicator = (a/b*100)%, where: a = number of government officers who completed the training sessions. b = estimated number of government officers who are likely to be involved in the design and implementation of policies impacting rural livelihoods (revised each year)... definition information sources sources for elementary indicator a: activity reports of the programme. for elementary indicator b: needs assessment performed in the design phase of the programme. it is revised each year based on consultations with the national government.

%currentslide%/%totalslides5% please select the answer of your choice let's imagine that three years after the launch of the programme, sharifa finds out that: seventy percent of government officers have completed the training session. how should she consider that result? defining your indicator as a success. as a failure. unable to judge.

%currentslide%/%totalslides5% every indicator should include a baseline and a target. baseline and target defining the baseline values will usually be done with a baseline study, which is performed during the first year of the programme. this is especially true for output and outcome indicators, as well as context indicators. baseline defining the targets to be reached is more problematic and usually requires a mix of experience of such programmes, good knowledge of the context and a touch of audacity. doing it in partnership with the programme's stakeholders will make it much easier, and will disseminate your objectives.be prepared to revise these targets in light of the observed results, especially after the first year of activity and after the mid-term evaluation. target

sharifa defines a baseline, which is an estimation based on a previous programme, and sets the targets for the mid-programme and end-of-programme. %currentslide%/%totalslides5% baseline and target fifteen percent (54 government officers were trained in a previous project, against an estimated target of 360). year 3: 50 percent year 5 (end of programme): 75 percent baseline target she also explains how the target was set: "note that due to transfers and new arrivals, the persons included in the target change every year. besides, we know from the previous project that some officers are reluctant to join the courses. therefore, we believe that 75 percent is a realistic, yet ambitious target." comments note that the comments section can be completed later on in the programme, to record aspects that will be useful when interpreting the results.

%currentslide%/%totalslides5% baseline and target voilà! we have built a full indicator table. this template is standard and you can use it to develop your indicators and to communicate about them. print the table in word format

%currentslide%/%totalslides5% please select the answer of your choice is it sensitive enough? checking quality a programme indicator must vary significantly once the programme is implemented and begins to produce effects. this sensitivity is easy to achieve at the output level, but you should take care to ensure it exists at outcome and impact levels. for example, imagine that you plan to put stakeholders around the table to discuss ways to avoid food price volatility in the national market. would you use the following indicator at outcome level? domestic food price volatility. yes. no.

%currentslide%/%totalslides5% please select the answer of your choice ignore this; nobody will know. provide a common definition. provide a checklist of relevant organizations that your programme targets. your partners and yourself should be able to trust the produced information. if you are collecting the information, you will be able to ensure that the data collection process is transparent. you need to be more careful when others are producing the information you will be using. is it reliable and credible? checking quality for instance, imagine that you are funding, for the first time, local ngos to organize partnership events and you want to know if they were a success. after the first round of events, you discover that each ngo counts participants differently. for instance, some count the number of persons registered; some, the number of attendees; while others add up each day's participants (50 on the first day + 40 on the second = 90 participants). you can't choose to add up the figures to gain an accurate view of participant involvement. what could you do to solve this issue?

and, finally, your indicators will be even better if... %currentslide%/%totalslides5% checking quality ...they are based on data that is recent enough. there may be some lag between the moment when the information is collected and the moment when you can use it for m&e. this is particularly true for context indicators relying on national statistics. make sure that the information will not be obsolete when you will be using it. do you know about smart criteria? ...they are comparable with other indicators used inside and outside your organization. using generic indicators will help to ensure this, but at the risk of not being sensitive and specific enough. ...they have a target value to reach. this value will help with interpretation of indicators and decision-making.

choosing indicators has consequences. use with caution! let's conclude this lesson with a few tips to identify and correct biases when using indicators. using a given indicator to measure a situation or a process can influence and "distort" the situation or the process itself. these phenomena are rarely malicious processes. however, you should be aware of them and take corrective measures if required. %currentslide%/%totalslides5% conclusion click on the buttons to see some examples of m&e questions example goodhart's and campbell's laws example example the observer effect

job aids now it’s your turn! you can use this template to develop your indicators and to detail how they will be measured: indicators table check the quality of your indicators with the grid provided here: checking the quality of your indicators %currentslide%/%totalslides5%

summary 1/2 an indicator is not just a ratio or a number. to make sure that its meaning, measurement and interpretation is unequivocal, you should define it in an accurate way, as well as identify the information source, baseline and target for each indicator. choosing indicators is about striking the right balance between what you need and what you can really do. there should be enough indicators so that all the major outputs and outcomes of the programme are covered, but not so many that the m&e system becomes a burden to the very programme it is supposed to serve. it is also advisable to consider information available at project level and indicators used in your organization. %currentslide%/%totalslides5%

summary 2/2 in addition, to make sure you have identified a good quality indicator, you should also check that: it measures what it should; its meaning is unequivocal; you have the capacity to measure it; it is sensitive enough; it is reliable and credible. %currentslide%/%totalslides5%

lesson 6: planning for m&e activities during the programme's lifetime 45 minutes this lesson gives you some practical suggestions for collection, analysis and reporting of data, and management of data and resources during your programme's lifetime.

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% learning objectives at the end of this lesson, you will be able to: identify options for data collection to address different information needs; describe the issues to consider when you plan for data analysis and reporting; identify the elements to plan with regard to human resources; be aware of data management issues.

basic m&e concepts defining your indicators choosing what to monitor planning for m&e activities m&e indicators: basic concepts introduction %currentslide%/%totalslides6% thanks to the work done previously, you have selected a small set of indicators that you will use to track the programme’s results. now, it’s time to plan how you will feed the system, who will be in charge and how you will react to the information obtained. planning for m&e activities

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% without planning, there is no implementation. introduction planning data collection this lesson will provide guidance on: planning analysis and reporting planning forresources planning data management your colleagues will give you some tips and answer common questions, based on their experience with m&e. click on mulat, clara and leila when you meet them throughout the lesson. mulat leila ask your colleagues clara

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% planning data collection planning data collection as you can see, it is important to ask questions before formulating indicators. you already know how to define and detail your indicators. now, you have to decide how to collect them. this is usually an iterative process, where you try to compromise between your actual information needs, your technical ability to collect data and the resources you can dedicate to data collection, i.e. what budget, what human resources and what level of priority. there are three main types of data that you can use: we will look at these options in the next screens. type 1 click on each type to read more type 2 type 3

planning baseline studies %currentslide%/%totalslides6% from the moment the indicators have been finalized, you will need to launch a baseline study, which will be the first measurement of the indicators. some organizations also schedule an end line study, in which the same indicators as in the baseline study are calculated and changes are analysed. baseline end line the baseline study will provide a measure against which progress can be assessed every year and at the end of the programme. it can also help you better understand the needs of your target. baseline and end line studies can also focus on important assumptions and risks, that you will not be able to track on an annual basis, but which can help you understand the results observed. planning data collection

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% planning data collection what you can do if you are not able to do a fully-fledged baseline study? for instance, if you monitor how high enhancing rural livelihoods is as a priority for government officials or agriculture stakeholders, you could ask interviewees in your baseline survey to rank it among a dozen other priorities. then, at mid-term review, you could do it again to see whether it climbed in the ranking or not. baseline studies are especially useful to provide a basis for the monitoring of outcomes. this monitoring often done via a survey, especially when the expected results come as improved knowledge, changing attitudes or new practices.

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% most of the indicators of your m&e system will likely need to be calculated every year, and sometimes twice a year, to be included in the annual report. you will need to retrieve information drawn from the operation and management of programme activities. this must be planned before the activities start. all this information can easily be asked of project beneficiaries using an application form first, and an evaluation questionnaire at the end of the training session. i need to know the number of attendees, their details, but also their profile (i.e. age, gender, residence, job, etc.), whether they are satisfied or not, whether they would recommend the training to others or whether they think they have learned something new that they will use... sharifa's programme includes an array of training projects, which are operated by training centres across the country. there is a lot of useful information that those operators can easily retrieve in their day-to-day activity. how to collect data from operators tips to collect data effectively planning for annual reports planning data collection

trace a fact that proves the existence of something. testimony a statement or an opinion about the existence of something. %currentslide%/%totalslides6% at outcome level, you will also often need to collect specific data by yourself. there are two main types of evidence that you are likely to rely on: "traces" and "testimonies". collecting specific data planning data collection new public commitments by government; new policies designed, endorsed and implemented; mention of strategic objectives of your organization in the law. notation by expert panel of the current legislative framework compared to organizational objectives. for example...

%drag01% %currentslide%/%totalslides6% %drag02% %drag03% check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer %drag04% sharifa has collected the following evidence in the framework of her priority on improving rural livelihoods. can you classify them as traces or testimonies? please drag and drop the items in the corresponding box and click on check answer survey of agriculture stakeholders about the evolution of coordination process with governments. survey of agriculture stakeholders about the evolution of coordination process with governments. production of studies on rural livelihoods by national government. production of studies on rural livelihoods by national government. existence of coordination mechanisms with agriculture stakeholders in terms of attendance at the meetings.. existence of coordination mechanisms with agriculture stakeholders in terms of attendance at the meetings.. survey of government officers who were trained, about the knowledge and competencies they acquired and how they used it. survey of government officers who were trained, about the knowledge and competencies they acquired and how they used it. planning data collection traces testimonies

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% how to collect traces and testimonies? traces are often retrieved by documentary analysis (e.g. legislation analysis), but in many cases it is lengthy and tedious work. an alternative solution is to ask insiders about these traces; for example, by organizing a workshop to review the legislation activity over the past 12 months (i.e. testimony). testimonies can be collected via interviews, workshops and surveys. surveying your targets is an excellent way to retrieve information, especially about changes in terms of knowledge, attitudes and practices (kap). surveys: are good at monitoring outcomes, which is what we want to do in programme m&e; provide quantitative measurements which are easy to use; are quite easy and cheap to implement, especially when you can survey the population online. should you plan for a sample survey? how often should you organize a survey? tips for preparing surveys and reading survey results. planning data collection

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% other organizations are probably collecting data in the country, either for: a statistical purpose (e.g. national agriculture institutes); m&e purposes (e.g. other international programmes); other reasons (ngo's public watch on governments, for instance). relying on data collected by other organizations planning data collection finally, remember to conduct data collection in an ethical manner. how to deal with external information.

annual reports mid-term evaluation final evaluation the reporting mechanisms of your programme have probably been set already. each programme may have its own specificities, but the reporting mechanisms usually include: %currentslide%/%totalslides6% planning data analysis and reporting planning analysis and reporting annual reports, which present the outputs of the monitoring system - usually along the results matrix - and try to explain the observed variations. an intermediate evaluation, which focuses on the first outcomes as well as on the relevance, and internal and external coherence of the programme. a final evaluation, which looks at the impacts of the programme, and tries to answer the question: did the programme make a difference, and how?

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% click on the arrow to proceed calculate the indicators and compare the level attained to the expected target; perform additional analysis, when the indicators are below target, such as disaggregating the data coming from the project level. present the indicators in a meeting with the m&e committee (also called a "critical reflection event"). planning data analysis and reporting annual reports for instance, if the number of participants in the training sessions is well below expectations, is there any type of participant who did not come? did all training sessions suffer from low attendance, or only some of them? every year, the programme manager (or the m&e specialist) should:

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% why is better to discuss collectively? planning data analysis and reporting following the committee's recommendations you will have to make some decisions. you can use a scoring process to help you make the correct decisions. the scoring process, if done collectively, is a good way to provoke discussion about the definition of the problem, how serious it is and how to correct it. green would mean that no decision is needed, or that only minor tweaks are required. yellow would indicate that corrective measures are needed to get the programme back on track. red would indicate that corrective measures are needed, but that they may not be sufficient to sort out the problems. for example, if you use "traffic light" reporting:

...to be taken when the problem comes from the way the activity is implemented. ...needed when the strategy and objectives appear to be inadequate. ...made when a situation is unexpected, or when no decision can be taken to correct the problem. %currentslide%/%totalslides6% planning data analysis and reporting don't forget to follow-up! the decisions you may have to make are usually of three different types: let's look at a few examples... operational measures strategic measures knowledge measures

problem 1 participants in the training sessions tell us that they do not use the knowledge acquired. apparently, they are unable to advocate for inclusion of the concepts into their hierarchy and, therefore, do not have an occasion to apply what they have learned. problem 2 only men come to our sessions, despite our efforts to include women, but we don’t know why. problem 3 our strategy was to train national level government officers to better control the implementation of national laws on rural livelihoods. but we realized that this control is actually done at local level. %currentslide%/%totalslides6% please select the answer of your choice for each problem do these problems call for operational, strategic or knowledge measures? planning data analysis and reporting knowledge operational strategic knowledge operational strategic knowledge operational strategic

one for your own team %currentslide%/%totalslides6% make sure that your figures are accompanied by an interpretation. planning data analysis and reporting are you collecting more information than is needed to comply with reporting requirements? if this extra information is useful for decision-making, then consider having two reports: ...which gives a wealth of details to explain the current state of achievement of the programme. it can be a good way to share the lessons learned from the programme with the staff. one (or several) for the outside ...which should be shorter and especially concentrate on: the answer to information needs; explanations about the situation observed and how it may evolve in the foreseeable future; decisions that are taken. you will be able to extract from this report the content needed for the required report(s).

internally, we have previously mentioned the "internal report". an annual m&e workshop with the staff is a good way to share information and an opportunity to celebrate when the results are good. %currentslide%/%totalslides6% planning data analysis and reporting communicating m&e results in an effective way is very important. implementing an m&e system takes some time. therefore, you should make sure that its results (and how you made your decisions based on the results) are widely shared. externally, you should share the lessons you have learned with other international and national organizations, at national or cross-regional levels. you can also participate in online communities of practice such as fao's global forum on food security and nutrition.

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% mid-term and final evaluations are an opportunity to collect specific data about the outcomes and, sometimes, the impacts of your programme. the evaluation process tends to be a longer process than the annual review: you need to ask specific questions (e.g. based on the questions that arose in the m&e committee in the previous years). you also need to plan for data collection, analysis and reporting. the entire process may take up to a year. furthermore, evaluations are usually conducted by independent teams that are either internal or external to your organization. this process helps avoid conflicts of interest. mid-term and final evaluations planning data analysis and reporting

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% planning for resources planningfor resources it's important to understand what are the existing m&e capacities in your programme team and among partners. ask the following three questions: is there m&e expertise among the programme team? is there m&e support from your organization or any other that you can rely on? can it be made available for that specific programme? do partners have any experience in m&e? you should plan for the needed human resources as early as possible in the programme. if the answer to these questions is rather negative, you will need to rely on an external m&e specialist who can help you improve your m&e plan. they will be able to train your team or to hire an m&e officer for your programme, if resources are available. otherwise, you can rely on your organization's or your partners' expertise to build your m&e system and develop capacity.

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% planning for resources who will do what in the m&e system? it is important to clearly define roles and responsibilities. the first step is to designate who will be in charge of the m&e system overall. it is usually the m&e officer or the programme manager, who will also be the resource person for her or his colleagues. in addition, the main tasks that will have to be performed, are: collecting the data calculating the indicators interpreting the indicators’ values reporting on the indicators click on each icon to know who is responsible

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% planning for resources what are your m&e training and support requirements? by comparing the current m&e capacity of your team and the m&e tasks that need to be performed, you will be able to identify what gaps you may need to fill with training and learning activities, for example: self-paced learning what for? how to do it? staff training activity coaching training, learning by doing and sharing are good ways to build a culture of m&e in your programme, which, in turn, can contribute to better commitment to the programme's achievement. sharing best practices click on each tab to read more

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% please select the answers of your choice (2 or more) and click on check answer what could she recommend to her colleagues who want to know more? in sharifa's team, every programme officer is responsible for collecting and aggregating some of the data that goes into the m&e system. %manswercorrect% %manswerincorrect% check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer check answer self-training. collective staff training. learning by doing. sharing best practices. planning for resources

%currentslide%/%totalslides6% planning for resources within the first year of your programme, make sure that you know what are the costs to plan for. these usually include: click on each icon to know more how much you should dedicate to m&e? expertise staff reporting data collecting and analysis

last but not least, make sure that you plan for data management. remember, that you will start collecting data that should be available at least for the duration of the programme, and even longer, if you consider the information needs of an ex-post evaluation , for instance. %currentslide%/%totalslides6% data management click on each tab to read more data organization planning data management the ifrc guide on m&e proposes seven key considerations that you can make your own: dataformat data availability data quality control information technology responsibility and accountability data security and legalities

defining your indicators conclusions %currentslide%/%totalslides6% choosing what to monitor planning for m&e activities basic m&e concepts m&e indicators: basic concepts congratulations! you now know everything you need to know to get started with m&e.

job aids now it’s your turn! you can answer the questions in the template below to define your m&e activities during the programme's lifetime: %currentslide%/%totalslides6% guiding questions for planning for m&e activities

summary 1/2 defining the right indicators is not enough. it is equally important to plan how you will feed the system, who will be in charge and how you will react to the information obtained. first, you should decide how you will collect data: for baseline and end line studies, reviews or evaluations; for annual reporting; and/or through other organizations. is it also crucial to plan for data analysis and reporting, in order to be able to provide timely recommendations and adopt appropriate measures to improve the programme's performance. you will have to assess the existing m&e capacities in your programme team and among partners. %currentslide%/%totalslides6%

summary 2/2 by comparing the current capacity of your team and the tasks that need to be performed, you will be able to identify what gaps you may need to fill with training and learning activities. within the first year of your programme, make sure that you know and plan for the costs. last but not least, make sure that you plan for data management. %currentslide%/%totalslides6%

course complete you have just completed the last lesson in your course. if it is the last lesson you had to complete, congratulations, you have now finished the course "developing a monitoring and evaluation plan for food security and agriculture programmes"! before you leave, take a look at the next few screens to know who has contributed to creating this course, to access useful resources and for updates on the upcoming e-learning on other courses fao.

thank you for completing the course thank you for completing the course! learning with us does not stop here. visit the fao learning center website for news and updates regarding this course and to keep informed about other courses. exit course exit course exit course exit course exit course exit course
acknowledgements partners click on each tab to read more references authors credits
